metadata.case_name: Omnibus Owners v. State of Tamil Nadu
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal Nos. 2415 of 1972 and 128 to 132 of 1973

facts.text: Petitioner is owner of omnibus with capacity for 54 passengers, obtained permit on 16-5-1968 to operate as contract carriage, paying tax at Rs. 30 per seat per quarter under Madras Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1931.
Madras Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1931 passed to abolish levy of tolls and taxes by local bodies; original rate Rs. 10 per seat per quarter, increased to Rs. 30 when permits system introduced.
G.O.M.S. 923-Home dated 19-4-1969 increased tax on omnibuses from Rs. 30 to Rs. 50 per seat per quarter effective 1-7-1969 to avoid unhealthy competition with stage carriages and misuse.
Owners challenged 1969 G.O. in Writ Petition No. 1412 of 1969 etc.
During pendency, G.O.M.S. 434-Home dated 27-2-1970 increased tax from Rs. 50 to Rs. 100 per seat per quarter effective 1-9-1970 to avoid unhealthy competition.

Writ petitions filed challenging 1970 G.O.; Madras High Court by common judgment dated 29-1-1971 quashed both 1969 and 1970 notifications, holding them device to eliminate contract carriages, not exercise of taxation power; tax restored to Rs. 30.
Appeals preferred to Supreme Court against High Court decision.
G.O.M.S. 2544 Home dated 20-1-1971 (G.O. No. 2044-Home dated 20-9-1971 in appeals) enhanced tax from Rs. 30 to Rs. 100 per seat per quarter effective 1-7-1971 under s.4 of 1931 Act.
Government incurred Rs. 19.51 crores in 1970-71 on maintenance and construction of roads; receipts from vehicle tax Rs. 16.38 crores; does not include grants to local bodies.
Stage carriages limited to 250 miles per day, fixed routes/schedules, certified roads; contract carriages unlimited miles, any route/time, any road.
Rate on stage carriages Rs. 65 per seat per quarter plus surcharge; contract carriages no surcharge.

legal_issues.text: Whether enhancement of motor vehicles tax on omnibuses from Rs. 30 to Rs. 100 per seat per quarter by G.O. No. 2044-Home dated 20-9-1971 is constitutionally valid.
Whether distinction between contract carriages and stage carriages in levy of vehicle tax offends Article 14.
Whether tax is restriction on freedom of trade, commerce under Article 301 not saved by Article 304(b) as notification lacks President's previous sanction.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notification not measure of taxation but device to eliminate competition of omnibuses with stage carriages run by Government.
Tax neither compensatory nor regulatory, restricts Article 301; as notification not law with President's previous sanction, invalid under Article 304(b).
Tax excessive, unreasonable restriction on right to carry on business.
No reason for higher tax on contract carriages than stage carriages; both similarly situated re road use; classification unreasonable under Article 14.
Levy not compensatory as includes capital cost of new roads construction.

respondent_arguments.text: Tax imposed under s.4 of 1931 Act; motive immaterial if power exists.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1931 s.4

respondent_arguments.text: Tax compensatory for road use/maintenance; receipts less than expenditure.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Automobile Transport (Rajasthan) Ltd. v. State of Rajasthan

respondent_arguments.text: Contract carriages cause more wear/tear: unlimited miles, any road/time/speed vs stage carriages' limits.

court_reasoning.text: Motive for tax immaterial if power under s.4 exists; no colourable exercise plea sustainable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Authority with power to tax valid regardless of reason.

court_reasoning.text: Tax compensatory, not restriction under Article 301 per Automobile case; rough approximation sufficient, not exact mileage; US precedents support flat fees if reasonable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proceeds < road costs; includes maintenance, construction, traffic control.

court_reasoning.text: Capital construction costs includable; receipts insufficient even excluding; no proof otherwise.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tax fair contribution to road costs.

court_reasoning.text: No material tax confiscatory or unreasonable under Article 19(1)(g); compensatory tax commensurate service.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No right to trade without paying for facilities.

court_reasoning.text: Classification contract vs stage carriages reasonable: contract run more miles, any roads, cause more damage; petitioners failed to disprove; presumption of validity in tax laws.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Burden on challenger; local conditions justify.

holdings.text: Enhancement of tax to Rs. 100 per seat valid; compensatory, not Art 301 restriction.
Distinction between contract and stage carriages for tax rates does not violate Art 14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Atiabari Tea Co. v. State of Assam
precedents_cited.relevance: Held taxes directly restricting trade within Art 301; overruled in part by Automobile case.

precedents_cited.case_name: Automobile Transport (Rajasthan) Ltd. v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Compensatory/regulatory taxes not restrictions under Art 301; clarified Atiabari.

precedents_cited.case_name: Khyerbari Tea Co. Ltd. v. State of Assam
precedents_cited.relevance: Affirmed Automobile; regulatory/compensatory measures outside Art 301.

precedents_cited.case_name: Amalgamated Tea Estates v. State of Kerala
Murthy Match Works v. Asstt. Collector of Central Excise

statutes_cited.name: Madras Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1931
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers government to notify tax rates; basis for notifications.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Tested for equality, trade freedom, restrictions.

statutes_cited.name: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines contract/stage carriages; permit conditions justifying classification.

statutes_cited.name: Tamil Nadu Motor Vehicles Taxation of Passengers and Goods Act, 1952

outcome.summary: Court dismissed civil appeals and writ petitions upholding validity of G.O. enhancing tax on omnibuses operated as contract carriages to Rs. 100 per seat per quarter as compensatory and non-discriminatory.
outcome.costs: without any order as to costs

key_quotes.text: "If an authority has power to impose a tax, the fact that it gave a wrong reason for exercising the power would not derogate from the validity of the tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "For a tax to become a prohibited tax, it has to be a direct tax, the effect of which is to hinder the movement part of the trade. If the tax is compensatory or regulatory, it cannot operate as a restriction."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines when tax falls under Art 301.

key_quotes.text: "A person who challenges a classification as unreasonable has the burden of proving it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
